Mortality for the Stanley, Idaho Study Area</resTitle><presForm xmlns=""><PresFormCd value="005" Sync="TRUE" /></presForm><citRespParty xmlns=""><rpIndName>Ben Bright</rpIndName><rpOrgName>University esriExtentType="search"><exTypeCode Sync="TRUE">1</exTypeCode><westBL Sync="TRUE">-115.193189</westBL><eastBL Sync="TRUE">-115.001294</eastBL><northBL Sync="TRUE">44.371680</northBL><southBL Sync="TRUE">44.247075</southBL></GeoBndBox></geoEle></dataExt><idPurp>A classiflication of tree mortality based on aggregated digital orthoimagery and LiDAR imagery</idPurp><idAbs><DIV STYLE="text-align:Left;"><DIV><DIV><P><SPAN>This raster layer is a supervised maximum likelihood classification of bark beetle-caused tree mortality based on aggregated digital orthoimagery and LiDAR imagery from Central Idaho. The imagery was collected in August 2010. </SPAN></P></DIV></DIV></DIV></idAbs><idCredit>Idaho NSF EPSCoR, University of Idaho</idCredit><searchKeys><keyword>Mountain Pine Beetle</keyword><keyword>Tree Mortality</keyword><keyword>insect outbreak</keyword><keyword>aerial imagery</keyword><keyword>LiDAR</keyword><keyword>supervised maximum likelihood classification</keyword></searchKeys><resConst><Consts xmlns=""><useLimit><DIV STYLE="text-align:Left;"><DIV><DIV><P><SPAN>Proper credit to Idaho NSF </SPAN><SPAN><SPAN>EPSCoR and authors.</SPAN></SPAN></P></DIV></DIV></DIV></useLimit></Consts></resConst><dataChar><CharSetCd value="004" /></dataChar><suppInfo>We aggregated original 0.2-m, four-band (blue, green, red, and near-infrared) digital orthoimagery to 2.4-m spatial resolution. Using this aggregated imagery, we produced Red Green Index (RGI; red band / green band) and Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) images. From coincident LiDAR data, we created a 2.4-m canopy height model (CHM) as well. Pixels with a near-infrared value < 0.15, a red value < 0.15, and a CHM value of < 0.5 m were masked as water, shadow, and non-forest, respectively. Of the remaining pixels, those with a RGI value of 1.08 were classified as dead red trees. Remaining pixels were classified as either green trees or dead gray trees using a supervised maximum likelihood classifier that used near infrared, RGI, and NDVI variables. Training and evaluation data came from field observations gathered while imagery was acquired. Overall classification accuracy was 87%. Classification was done using Environment for Visualizing Images (ENVI) software. For details, see Bright, B.C., Hicke, J.A., and Hudak, A.T. 2012. Estimating aboveground carbon stocks of a forest affected by mountain pine beetle in Idaho using lidar and multispectral imagery. Remote Sensing of Environment, 124: 270-281 and Bright, B.C., Hicke, J.A., and Hudak, A.T. 2012. Landscape-scale analysis of aboveground tree carbon stocks affected by mountain pine beetles in Idaho. Environmental Research Letters, 7, 045702.</suppInfo><idStatus><ProgCd value="001" /></idStatus></dataIdInfo><distInfo xmlns=""><distFormat xmlns=""><formatName Sync="TRUE">Raster Dataset</formatName></distFormat><distTranOps xmlns=""><onLineSrc
